user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_:
```c
void
MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  /* Cache 'daemon' here to avoid data races */
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->urh);
  mhd_assert (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME));

  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  connection->urh->was_closed = true;
  connection->resuming = true;
  daemon->resuming = true;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  if ( (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc)) &&
       (! MHD_itc_activate_ (daemon->itc, "r")) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to signal resume via " \
                 "inter-thread communication channel.\n"));
#endif
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No uses of the <string.h> functions named in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 are present in this function. There are no calls to memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, or any other standard string-handling function. The code only performs pointer dereferences, member assignments, mutex operations, assertions, and calls to MHD_itc_activate_ and logging macros. The only string literal in this fragment is "r" passed to MHD_itc_activate_; passing a literal is not itself a <string.h> operation. Similarly, the logging/gettext macro usage (the _() and MHD_DLOG lines) uses string literals but does not invoke any of the string.h functions within this function. If the called functions (e.g., MHD_itc_activate_, MHD_DLOG or the expansion of _) internally use string.h functions, those internal implementations are outside the scope of this function and would need to be reviewed in their own definitions, not here. Therefore, there are no code fragments in this function that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
